top_comment.text:
Another form of study that I find questionable is the self-reporting survey 
or study...  Self-perception is often over-optimistic & deeply flawed.﻿
top_comment.author: WWZenaDo

comments.text:
Ah, it's just one of my favourite words, so I use it a lot. Harsh but not 
sweary.
comments.author: Emerson

comments.text:
+Emerson I cannot tell you how much I regret using that word "crappy" in my 
post above...  >;]P
comments.author: WWZenaDo

comments.text:
Crappy questions result in crappy questionnaires, which result in crappy 
data. Can't make decent conclusions based on crap data. But yeah, I agree 
with you, which is why psych degrees spend semesters teaching research 
methods stuff.
comments.author: Emerson

comments.text:
+Emerson I was primarily referring to studies that ask questions such as, 
"Do you feel you are a moral person?"  (Yeah, I know, crappy question, 
but...)  I mean, questions that are poorly crafted so that the 
respondent's  often idealized perception of themselves interferes with the 
reality of how they actually would react in challenging situations.
comments.author: WWZenaDo

comments.text:
But when you're studying something such as...mental illness symptoms or 
personality, the factors involved can often only be perceived internally. 
So they can ONLY be studied by self-report. It all depends on what you're 
actually studying.
comments.author: Emerson

top_comment.text:
Not being scrutinously picky, but the maze example is a little flawed; if 
you had more energy (leading to jitteriness and lack of concentration when 
at rest) then one could be faster through the maze by simply /going/ faster 
than the others.﻿
top_comment.author: TheWulf899

comments.text:
Agreed. I think solving a couple of 40-60 pieces jigsaw puzzles might be 
the best way to test this. With one puzzle the chance of coincidences is 
pretty high. With a couple of different puzzles it would pretty reliable if 
you selected your different groups considering their training in recent 
years with puzzles.
comments.author: Joachim Schoder

comments.text:
+TheWulf899 +Diana mh +QuickFireGaming 1) In Maze studies, you correct for 
speed, or you measure turns taken instead of time taken for instance, 2) 
you WOULD normally test both people on caffeine and off caffeine, this way 
you can keep your sample size low but still retain statistical power and 
you would then also correct for familiarity with mazes. I order to prevent 
carryover effects from the first run as much as possible, you randomize the 
order in which test subjects perform either first with caffeine or first 
without it :) [edit] And then, if your sample size is large enough, you 
could check whether or not there ARE any carryover effects and if not, BAM 
statistical power smack on your countenance.
comments.author: Paul Mertens

comments.text:
It's a joke. Hank is being observed in his natural environment by the 
mini-scientist as he talks about naturalistic observation.
comments.author: Jack Diseker

comments.text:
+Diana mh No, that does not flaw the test because there is equal chance 
that those that could walk faster or have more experience with mazes or 
where simply lucky end up in the same test group. If the sample sizes are 
large enough (or the experiment is replicated often enough) than the law of 
large numbers will flatten out those variables and you will see the 
difference actually produced by the variable (the coffee or lack thereof).

Actually making the same person run the maze twice would(!) invalidate the 
test because the earlier runs (with or without coffee) have the ability to 
influence the later runs in various unpredictable ways.
comments.author: Brian Bors

comments.text:
I took "Navigate a maze" to mean On Paper. I guess it wasn't explicit, but 
perhaps implied by the average experimental budget of psychologists.
comments.author: Swungover

comments.text:
+Diana mh That is why you would try to have a large sample size (number of 
people) for both the control group and the test group. No test is perfect, 
especially in psychology.
comments.author: QuickFireGaming

comments.text:
Which is why the hypothesis that the experiment will be proving true or 
false is that "adult humans given coffee will navigate a maze faster than 
adult humans not given coffee". The hypothesis says nothing about 
intelligence and the initial question said nothing about intelligence 
either so that part isn't flawed. Of course in a real experiment that would 
try to prove something to a scientific community they would be doing some 
heavy analyses of the data to determine the most likely reason for a faster 
completion of the maze.
comments.author: QuickFireGaming

top_comment.text:
Um, what the heck does getting through a maze have to do with 
quick-thinking and focus???﻿
top_comment.author: Krystalcove

comments.text:
Not really... getting through a maze is about quick legs and luck. If you 
are solving a maze on a piece of paper you can see the whole thing and then 
you can visualize and try to solve it. But an in-person maze is just trial 
and error.
comments.author: Krystalcove

comments.text:
You just answered your own question....getting through a maze as fast as 
possible is ALL ABOUT quick-thinking and focus!
comments.author: Lizzy Bee

comments.text:
I'm confused.  You're saying quick-thinking and focus aren't required in 
order to solve problems quickly?  A maze is a pretty typical application 
for these two things.  Getting through a maze quickly even more-so. I guess 
I'm not seeing the issue.

The question and the hypothesis do not have to match exactly.  In many 
instances they will not match up, and sometimes there won't even be a 
question at all.  The hypothesis, and whether its tests can be replicated 
faithfully by another disinterested party, is what matters.  The results 
can inform the question after research concludes.
comments.author: Thom Wilson

comments.text:
Yes but her original question, i.e. step one of the process, does not match 
with their hypothesis and example. (It doesn't matter if it's relateable if 
it's wrong.) 
Well, not wrong, but a little misleading maybe?
comments.author: Krystalcove

comments.text:
Caffeine was used to make the video's overall thesis relatable. Whether 
it's true or not is irrelevant; they just needed some random question to 
demonstrate how a hypothesis is examined using accepted scientific 
processes.
comments.author: Thom Wilson

top_comment.text:

top_comment.author: swishman

comments.text:
+swishman Psychoanalysis is a completely unscientific practice. Its 
continued place in public awareness is one reason why I am so glad to see a 
CC in psychology. It also offers an explanation as to why this episode on 
methodology is so important: it is likely not common knowledge that modern 
therapies (e.g., cognitive-behavioral therapy) usually have some basis in 
empirical findings. There remains a gap between clinical practices and 
research but the research is usually there and it relies on the scientific 
method.
comments.author: Nathan Stroh

comments.text:
Firstly; my syntactic arrangement was compromised by my drunkeness. 
Secondly: I take a far more descriptive point of view to syntactic/ lexical 
prescriptive ideology than most, which is probably why I have had no books 
published. :)

I have not read 1984 so I offer no rebuttal to your likeness of my comment 
to it but I assume that my reference to totalitarianism is what has 
triggered your reference. 

You are neither psychologically deviant from the norm in your comments, nor 
within my parameters of study for me to psychoanalyse and I apologise for 
that. If you want to be psychoanalysed, please apply to relevant 
project studies in your locality or even public groups which offer this 
service.

Finally the "theory of mind" may be something you should read up on and 
"apathy" is not the word you are looking for: maybe "ignorance" which is 
not used inappropriately as these videos are made to educate those who have 
NO PRIOR KNOWLEDGE in the subject of study (ergo those who are ignorant of 
the subject) but you already knew that.

Thank you for your constructive reply and as a final word of advice: don't 
take the bait that other responses have placed before mine.

comments.text:
+swishman I think this is meant to have more of a popular science approach 
rather than targeting more specialized audiences. I am a MA student in 
experimental psychology and I recognize the presentation is somewhat 
simplified but that is pop science. I still like it and think it has value. 
Personally, I just hope that by the end of this series, if I tell people I 
am a psychologist the majority will not yell "Freud!" or automatically 
assume I am a clinician and analyzing them. Right now, I say I am studying 
behavioral science to avoid those reactions. Most people do not realize 
that behavioral science and psychology are essentially synonymous.

comments.author: MrJackSpade

comments.text:
+swishman Maybe this says more about your own knowledge than the knowledge 
of the general public that he is attending to. You have no obligation to 
attend to his videos and should research academic articles in areas which 
YOU see fit to expand your knowledge in, if you find these things simple: 
see it as a compliment to your own pre-ordained cognitive psychological 
understanding which demonstrates the level you SHOULD attend to is higher 
than the level portrayed in this video. Personally I attend to 
supervise/recognise the content as both a student, and teacher, of English 
Language and Literature and of Cognitive Science. I would recommend you 
pursuit a course in Psychology if you are truly offended and after (or 
during) provide evidential support to your criticism as appropriate to the 
video's content and intended audience (by which time you should be 
educationally viable to support your argument). This is not de-constructive 
criticism; as I (as any) would be glad to have people attend to Psychology 
(or English studies) as a discipline as much as the next true student of 
Psychology. Please do not generalise "the people" as many totalitarian 
people have in their argument: if you find the subject simple then it 
reflects your ability and understanding more than their expression and 
"depth" of knowledge in this video. This is no specialist class: it 
portrays itself as being a "Crash Course". Read if you want to learn more, 
whether in academic books or using Google Scholar for articles: it doesn't 
matter. The pursuit of personal knowledge satisfaction and ergo 
contribution to humanity DOES matter. We are a people built on it. If you 
are angry please read and contribute relevant articles and theses before 
replying. I implore you to consider authorial intent of audience before 
judging audience even if that goes against Barthes theory that the "author 
is dead" because that does NOT satisfy all intent and therefore conditions 
for the work to be judged upon. In other words:if you find this simple move 
onto more complicated and challenging work which YOU WILL NOT FIND HERE. 
(the caps lock is for stress of intonation, not expression of anger) Thank 
you. P.S. Thank you the Green Brothers for giving INFORMATIONAL and clearly 
pedagogical content on YouTube. There is work underway to expand the 
pedagogical aspect further (no promises) but there is talk of such. I thank 
you for exploiting YouTube as a means as an informational medium.

top_comment.text:
Wouldn't that experiment be inaccurate unless everyone was equally good at 
traversing mazes (I.e. they all had the same sense of direction) before 
being given coffee?  It seems like it would be more accurate to put each 
individual through the maze without the influence of caffeine (as the 
control) and then compare that to how they each did under the influence of 
caffeine rather than doing groups. ﻿
top_comment.author: Griffian Sword

comments.text: +Zhou XiaoJian I suppose thats true,
comments.author: Griffian Sword

comments.text:
But due to the number of people in each group (some are good with maze some 
aren't), the result will average out. If the result is significantly 
different then they is highly likely that there's a correlation. If you 
were to let one person do it, then you gotta change the maze each time, you 
are introducing a new variable that way aka the difficulty of maze. 
Basically in science there's no 100% accuracy, we just try to maximize it.

top_comment.text:
When I attend a lecture I find the speakers that don't allow enough time 
between thoughts are the hardest to follow. I feel like the "Crash Course" 
videos are doing the same thing. They edit out any space or breath the 
speaker takes. When writing an essay a writer would make sure punctuation 
is correct and commas are used properly. This creates a realistic flow of 
words and sentences in essays. Listening to this video is like reading an 
essay with all those commas and periods taken out. In their attempt to 
maintain attention and make an efficient learning video Crash Course has 
created a piece of work that holds valuable information but uses a poor 
delivery. So much that the learning and memorizing process are slowed. 
Please edit your videos so they convey thoughts in a matter not solely 
focused on the amount of info shared in a short time but on the amount of 
info taught and retained most efficiently. I do appreciate the videos even 
though I feel they're a bit rushed. Thanks﻿
top_comment.author: LebannersHook

comments.text:
+LebannersHook At least you can pause it. I try to not to talk as fast as 
they do with the videos I make.
comments.author: Mr. Beat's Social Studies Channel

comments.text:
+LebannersHook They talk fast because it produces a constant flow of 
stimuli. They take advantage of being able to do this to the extent of what 
you see on television because of the rewind button. It's basically to 
generate more views and keep your average viewer from becoming 
disinterested. It can be annoying, but it's a good thing imo.
comments.author: LolroflJamesBond

comments.text:
My worry is that too many videos are becoming cramped so they can cut down 
the time it takes for someone to give them a view. I worry that people 
forget how to learn and retain information correctly. As I learned in my 
psychology class, remembering is a process. It involves repeating, applying 
and associating the subject that is being learned. Anyone who watches this 
will get a feeling that they understood much, but will retain very little. 
I would not leave the retaining and memorizing part of teaching up to the 
student. Just like using google instead of piling through a mental lexicon 
dumbs down a persons ability to recall information, these videos too teach 
people to bounce thoughts around in their head. They skip from one point to 
the next. Creating attention spans equivalent to that of a chipmunk. In a 
society marred by ADD, ADHD and learning disabilities I find it rather 
important that we work to increase students focus and attention instead of 
reinforcing bad learning habits like this video does. I understand that we 
can just rewind the video, but rewinding is not, and should not be part of 
the learning process.
comments.author: LebannersHook

comments.text:
+LebannersHook Yeah, do what +Caitlin Quick does, it really helps, it's not 
intended to be a long video because we can always rewind points that we 
don't comprehend immediately.

top_comment.text:
Statistically it is less probable to have 5 consecutive heads or 5 
consecutive tails than it is to have any randomized mixture of heads and 
tails. This is because 5 consecutive tails has the same probability of 5 
consecutive heads, or any other exact pattern, yet when adding up every 
other possibility, it is significantly greater than the singular possible 
specific pattern of pure heads or singular possible specific pattern of 
pure tails.﻿
top_comment.author: StupidButCunning

comments.text:
He didn't say randomized though, he said alternating, which is a specific 
pattern.

And, arguably, it's the pattern most humans "expect" because a 50/50 
probability is perceived as having equal outcomes.

Put plainly, most people will find it "normal" that 5 coin tosses yield 
either HTHTH or THTHT while find it unusual or even meaningful that 5 coin 
tosses yield TTTTT or HHHHH, but they're all equally likely.
comments.author: pmcdirewolf

comments.text:
you're right, but i guess they were referring to "any other specific 
pattern" -  say, HHTTT. That would still have a higher probability that 
HHHHH, though, except when you use five different coins and want a specific 
coin having a specific outcome.
comments.author: Blakekss

comments.text:
That is true, I just made the comment in reference to the tons of people in 
comments questioning how the probability worked out.

top_comment.author: Samuel Adams

comments.text:
+Eric Stamps You are very much correct. When i say gravity i refer to the 
non-relativistic gravity that we experience here on earth every day. 
Gravity is a lot more complicated if you look at a much larger scale, and 
the accuracy of relativistic gravity is still debated, even though it is 
very precise within the confines of our own galaxy. 
As you say, everything is different on the tiny scale that quantum physics 
works within, and it is the field of physics that we are the farthest from 
fully understanding.
comments.author: Simon Bækkegaard

comments.text:
+Simon Bækkegaard
Actually, even the theory of gravity is shaky. There are several different 
theories on gravity which they are trying reconcile. Correct me if I'm 
wrong, but relativity doesn't work on tiny objects, while quantum mechanics 
is typically only used on tiny particles. This is why I love science.
comments.author: Eric Stamps

comments.text: Thanks for the info :)
comments.author: Samuel Adams

comments.text:
That is actually why they say that, because a theory is NOT proven. The 
problem is that most scientific theories will forever remain theories 
forever, because there really is no way to prove a theory. That, though, 
does not mean that there is any doubt among scientists that the theory is 
wrong, because if the theory has been mistaken JUST ONCE, then it has been 
disproved, and if it has never been disproved in many years, like 
evolution, then it is a very solid theory (assuming there is actually a 
proper hypothesis)
Lets look at an example:
What we know about gravity itself is actually based on a theory. You really 
can't prove that gravity exists as we think it does, because if it just 
fails one time, fx if it is 10% weaker tomorrow, then the theory has been 
disproved and a new hypothesis has to be formed. As of right now, gravity 
follows the same rules every time, every where, and has never been proven 
untrue. It is a very sound theory with, enough so that we, like with 
evolution, can assume that it is true.
comments.author: Simon Bækkegaard

comments.text:
Beginning with the rise of behaviorism under John B. Watson in the early 
1900s, empirical research has been the basis of psychology. As such, the 
scientific method is as much a part of modern psychology as it is of any 
other science. Unfortunately, it is not what the field is known for in the 
general public. It is a misconception that we all end up as clinicians. 
Many PhDs in clinical psychology are employed teaching at universities and 
doing research. As a MA student in experimental psychology (behavioral 
science), I will offer the anecdote that almost every psychology textbook 
and course I have encountered in both my undergraduate and graduate career 
covers research methods in the first few lessons. Entire courses on 
research methods and quantitative methods are required at some point in 
both undergraduate and graduate coursework. Often the classes even serve, 
either unintentionally or intentionally, as bottleneck courses that can 
prevent students from progressing further in the degree. I will not deny 
that psychology has methodological issues, both historical (even Watson 
himself) and current, but there is an active movement to correct the 
problems. As you indicated, there are individuals who are more or less 
oriented to either hard or soft scientific methods. This does not 
necessarily make the entire science soft.
comments.author: Nathan Stroh

comments.text:
+Fencer Dave

comments.author: Slpk

comments.text:
+dangerouslytalented One version of the alternating is (H for heads, T for 
tails): HTHTH -- the other is THTHT. They're not the same. 

Regardless, all possibilities are equally likely. 5H or 5T just stick out 
as they seem to denote a pattern not unlike the alternating ones.

To expand your thinking, consider a lottery game where you pick a number 
0000-9999. All ten thousand possible combinations are equally likely to 
come up in one of those ball shuffling machines -- but that won't keep 
anyone from thinking things like 1000 or 5555 are less likely to occur 
than, say, 6423 or something. 

It's weird how our biases work.
comments.author: Nate Greene

comments.text: +elraito YAY Gambler's fallacy
comments.author: Agenda

comments.text:
I think what he meant is that the result HTHTH has the same chance of 
showing up than HHHHH or TTTTT or THTHT. The problem is that it wasn't 
worded clearly.

The second problem is that we humans like to group things together. So 
HTHTH usually is 3H and 2T. Since there is only one possibility to get this 
result when H and T alternate every coin flip, it is close enough. But when 
you don't have the information of the alternation, you suddenly have 
various possibilites in getting 3H and 2T. However, you still would only 
have one way in generating 5H, which is why this somehow becomes 
significant for us, because anyone can throw 3H and 2T, but 5H is something 
special.

In the end it boils down to the question if order is an important factor to 
consider or not. When order is important HHHHH is as special as HTHTH. When 
order is not important 5H is indeed rare.
comments.author: yan dere

comments.text:
And just in case since this is a series about psychology I want to point 
out that every coin toss has an independent chance for head or tails. Also 
every series is independent. People who get addicted to gambling have a 
tendency to think that if you toss the coins out over a long period of time 
and over a multitude of tossing you should close on to average 50/50 on the 
head or tail. And because of that when they get a series of say many heads 
in a row they may think that now getting tails is more likely because the 
coin tossing should close on to average forgetting that every coin toss 
will still be independent of previous tosses.

top_comment.text:
Question:
You mentioned that "coffee won't make you smart," but many people believe 
things like this to be true. For example: listening to Classical music as a 
child. 
So my question is:
Is our intelligence (not necessarily our IQ) pre-determined by our 
genetics? Was a person destined to be stupid? Or smart? CAN certain things 
make you "smarter?" Or can they just help us learn?
~Stevie, Minneapolis, MN﻿
top_comment.author: Stephanie Hottman

+Emerson I spent a lot of time in school trying to figure that out. I just 
want to be smarter without having to do much, haha!

it depends what you want to get good at. go look up multiple intelligences

comments.author: Stephanie Hottman

comments.text: Don't die of internal drowning! :P
comments.author: Emerson

comments.text:
Environment can play a huge role in how intelligence is viewed. In some 
places, in some families, in some economies, its just not valued and people 
don't live up to their potential. In others, its more important than 
anything else. 
And in these cases, intelligence and education are almost synonymous. 
Having a high level education doesn't mean someone is smarter than anyone 
else, it just means that that person had the resources to explore his/her 
intelligence. 
What if everyone had the opportunity to explore in the same way? The 
pressure might be off those who are expected to be smarter. And those who 
may not have even known they were smart could "fill in the gaps" so to 
speak. 
And just in case coffee DOES make me smarter, im going to go drink a 
Starbucks. Not a drink. The whole Starbucks.
comments.author: Stephanie Hottman

comments.text:
That is the Big Question. Psychologists have been trying to figure this out 
for over a hundred years. Go look at the intelligence wiki page and read 
through the history of the IQ (which is just the numbers we use to measure 
'intelligence'), it's really interesting. TLDR: we don't know, but yes. 
Partly genetics, partly environment.
comments.author: Emerson

top_comment.author: Lights Blade

comments.text:
Yeah. That experimental design had that one major flaw. Easy fix, though: 
rather than have adults run through a maze (which is also totally not 
cost-effective), give them a computerized (or paper-and-pencil) maze.

The computerized maze design will also open up avenues for 
repeated-measures designs (testing the same people at different levels of 
caffeination), because the maze can easily be changed to reduce or 
eliminate testing effects (and make the experiment way cheaper to run, 
because you aren't building a huge maze, and you don't necessarily have to 
recruit as many people to have a significant sample). On top of that, a 
paper/computer maze might give more accurate results, because maybe some 
people are just better at mazes than others; the repeated-measures design 
allows for testing of an individual's differential score (the difference 
between caffeinated & non-caffeinated maze times).

tl:dr; Use a paper maze.
comments.author: Jensen Stroup

it's not shitty, you just end up using more than one independent variable ,

gas characteristics, you learn that there are a couple of independent 
variables that you need to test and experiment with in order to obtain the 
formula PV=NrT for example, which basically states that there is a 
relationship between the temperature, the pressure, the quantity of gas and 
its volume, basically, by including more (related) factors to test, most of 
the time you end up with a more complete understanding of the studied 
phenomena

comments.text:
+Aifos Mujna My worry is that too many videos are becoming cramped so they 
can cut down the time it takes for someone to give them a view. I worry 
that people forget how to learn and retain information correctly. As I 
learned in my psychology class, remembering is a process. It involves 
repeating, applying and associating the subject that is being learned. 
Anyone who watches this will get a feeling that they understood much, but 
will retain very little. I would not leave the retaining and memorizing 
part of teaching up to the student. Just like using google instead of 
piling through a mental lexicon dumbs down a persons ability to recall 
information, these videos too teach people to bounce thoughts around in 
their head. They skip from one point to the next. Creating attention spans 
equivalent to that of a chipmunk. In a society marred by ADD, ADHD and 
learning disabilities I find it rather important that we work to increase 
students focus and attention instead of reinforcing bad learning habits 
like this video does. I understand that we can just rewind the video, but 
rewinding is not, and should not be part of the learning process. (already 
posted this but it is relevant here)

captions.text:
Can week-old pizza cause psychedelic hallucinations?
Does coffee make you smarter? Or does it just
make you do dumb stuff faster?

Like a bunch of psychology itself, questions
like this can seem pretty intuitive. I mean,

people may not be the easiest organisms to
understand, but you're a person, right? So

you must be qualified to draw, like, some
conclusions about other people and what makes
them tick.

But it's important to realize that your intuition
isn't always right. In fact, sometimes it

is exactly wrong, and we tend to grossly underestimate
the dangers of false intuition. If you have

an idea about a person and their behavior
that turns out to be right, that reinforces

your trust in your intuition. Like if one
of my buddies, Bob, begins eating that deep-dish

pizza that's been in the fridge for the past
week but he eats it anyway and soon starts

to wig out, I'll say "Dude, I told you so".
But if I'm wrong and he's totally fine, I
probably won't even think about it ever again.

This is known as 'Hindsight Bias" or the "I-Knew-It-All-Along"
phenomenon. This doesn't mean the common sense

is wrong, it just means that our intuitive
sense more easily describes what just happened,

than what will happen in the future. Another
reason you can't blindly trust your intuition

is your natural tendency toward overconfidence.
Sometimes, you just really, really feel like

you're right about people when actually you're
really, really wrong. We've all been there.

We also tend to perceive order in random events,
which can lead to false assumptions. For example,

if you flip a coin five times you have equal
chances of getting all tails as you do getting

alternating heads and tails. But we see the
series of five tails as something unusual,

as a streak, and thus giving that result some
kind of meaning that it very definitely does
not have.

That is why we have the methods and safe-guards
of psychological research and experimentation,

and the glorious process of scientific inquiry.
They help us to get around these problems

and basically save the study of our minds
from the stupidity of our minds. So I hope

that it won't be a spoiler if I tell you now
that pizza won't make you trip, and coffee
doesn't make you smart. Sorry.
[Intro]

In most ways psychological research is no
different than any other scientific discipline,

like step one is always figuring out how to
ask general questions about your subject and

turn them into measurable, testable propositions.
This is called operationalizing your questions.

So you know how the scientific method works
-- it starts with a question and a theory,

and I don't mean theory in the sense of like,
a hunch that say, a quad-shot of espresso

makes you think better. Instead, in science
a theory is what explains and organizes lots

of different observations and predicts outcomes.
And when you come up with a testable prediction,
that's your hypothesis.

Once your theory and hypothesis are in place,
you need a clear and common language to report

them with, so for example, defining exactly
what you mean by "thinking better" with your

espresso hypothesis will allow other researchers
to replicate the experiment. And replication

is key. You can watch a person exhibit a certain
behavior once, and it won't prove very much,

but if you keep getting consistent results,
even as you change subjects or situations,
you're probably on to something.

This is a problem with one popular type of
psychological research: case studies, which

take an in-depth look at one individual. Case
studies can sometimes be misleading, because

by their nature, they can't be replicated,
so they run the risk of over-generalizing.

Still, they're good at showing us what CAN
happen, and end up framing questions for more

extensive and generalizable studies. They're
also often memorable and a great story telling

device psychologists use to observe and describe
behavior. Like, say the smell of coffee makes

Carl suddenly anxious and irritable -- that
obviously doesn't mean that it has that same

effect on everyone. In fact, Carl has terrible
memories associated with that smell, and so

his case is actually quite rare. Poor Carl.
But you would still have to look at lots of
other cases to determine that conclusively.

Another popular method of psychological research
is naturalistic observation, where researchers

simply watch behavior in a natural environment,
whether that's chimps poking ant-hills in

the jungle, kids clowning in a classroom or
drunk dudes yelling at soccer games. The idea

is to let the subjects just do their thing
without trying to manipulate or control the

situation. So yeah, basically just spying
on people. Like case studies, naturalistic

observations are great at describing behavior,
but they're very limited in explaining it.

Psychologists can also collect behavioral
data using surveys or interviews, asking people

to report their opinions and behaviors. Sexuality
researcher Alfred Kinsey famously used this

technique when he surveyed thousands of men
and women on their sexual history and published

his findings in a pair of revolutionary texts,
Sexual Behavior in the Human Male and Female
respectively.

Surveys are a great way to access consciously
held attitudes and beliefs, but how to ask

the questions can be tricky; subtle word choices
can influence results. For example more forceful

words like "ban" or "censor" may elicit different
reactions than "limit" or "not allow". Asking

"Do you believe in space aliens?" is a much
different question than "Do you think that

there is intelligent life somewhere else in
the universe?" It's the same question, but

in the first the subject might assume you
mean aliens visiting earth, and making crop
circles and abducting people and poking them.

And if how you phrase surveys is important,
so is who you ask. I could ask a room full

of students at a pacifist club meeting what
they think about arms control, but the result

wouldn't be a representative measure of where
students stand, because there's a pretty clear

sampling bias at work here. To fairly represent
a population, I'd need to get a random sample

where all members of the target group, in
this case students, had an equal chance of
being selected to answer the question.

So once you've described behavior with surveys,
case studies, or naturalistic observation,

you can start making sense out of it, and
even predict future behavior. One way to do

that is to look at one trait or behavior is
related to another, or how they correlate.

So let's get back to my buddy Bob who seems
to think that his refrigerator is actually

some kind of time machine that can preserve
food indefinitely. Let's say that Bob has

just tucked into a lunch of questionable leftovers,
pizza that may very well have had a little

bit of fungus on it. But he was hungry, and
lazy, and so he doused it in Sriracha. Suddenly,

he starts seeing things: green armadillos
with laser beam eyes.

From here we could deduce that eating unknown
fungus predicts hallucination, that's a correlation.

But correlation is not causation. Yes, it
makes sense that eating questionable fungus

would cause hallucinations, but it's possible
that Bob was already on the verge of a psychotic

episode, and those fuzzy leftovers were actually
benign. Or there could be an entirely different

factor involved, like maybe he hadn't slept
in 72 hours, or had an intense migraine coming

on, and one of those factors caused his hallucinations.
It's tempting to draw conclusions from correlations,

but it's super-important to remember that
correlations predict the possibility of cause-and-effect
relationships; they cannot prove them.

So we've talked about how to describe behavior
without manipulating it and how to make connections

and predictions from those findings. But that
can only take you so far; to really get to

the bottom of cause-and-effect behaviors,
you're gonna have to start experimenting.

Experiments allow investigators to isolate
different effects by manipulating an independent

variable, and keeping all other variables
constant, or as constant as you can. This

means that they need at least two groups:
the experimental group, which is gonna get

messed with, and the control group, which
is not gonna get messed with.

Just as surveys use random samples, experimental
researchers need to randomly assign participants

to each group to minimize potential confounding
variables, or outside factors that may skew

the results. You don't want all grumpy teenagers
in one group and all wealthy Japanese surfers
in the other; they gotta mingle.

Now sometimes one or both groups are not informed
about what's actually being tested. For example,

researchers can test how substances effect
people by comparing their effects to placebos,

or inert substances. And often, the researchers
themselves don't know which group is experimental

and which is control, so they don't unintentionally
influence the results through their own behavior,

in which case it's called, you guessed it,
a double blind procedure.

So let's put these ideas into practice in
our own little experiment. Like all good work,

it starts with a question. So the other day
my friend Bernice and I were debating. We

were debating caffeine's effect on the brain.
Personally, she convinced that coffee helps

her focus and think better, but I get all
jittery like a caged meerkat and can't focus

on anything. And because we know that overconfidence
can lead you to believe things that are not
true, we decided to use some critical thinking.

So let's figure out our question: "Do humans
solve problems faster when given caffeine?"

Now we gotta boil that down into a testable
prediction. Remember: keep it clear, simple,

and eloquent so that it can be replicated.
"Caffeine makes me smarter" is not a great

hypothesis. A better one would be, say, "Adult
humans given caffeine will navigate a maze

faster than humans not given caffeine." The
caffeine dosage is your independent variable,

the thing that you can change. So, you'll
need some coffee. Your result or dependent

variable, the thing that depends on the thing
that you can change is going to be the speed

at which the subject navigates through this
giant corn maze.

Go out on the street, wrangle up a bunch of
different kinds of people and randomly assign

them into three different groups. Also at
this point, the American Psychological Association

suggests that you acquire everyone's informed
consent to participate. You don't want to

force anyone to be in your experiment, no
matter how cool you think it is.

So the control group gets a placebo, in this
case decaf. Experimental group one gets a

low dose of caffeine, which we'll define at
a 100 milligrams; just an eye opener, like,

a cup of coffee's worth. Experimental group
two gets 500 milligrams, more than a quad

shot of espresso dunked in a Red Bull. Once
you dose everyone, turn them lose in the maze
and wait at the other end with a stopwatch.

All that's left is to measure your results
from the three different groups and compare

them to see if there were any conclusive results.
If the highly dosed folks got through it twice

as fast as the low dose and the placebo groups,
then Bernice's hypothesis was correct, and

she can rub my face in it saying she was right
all along, but really that would just be the

warm flush of hindsight bias telling her something
she didn't really know until we tested it.

Then, because we've used clear language and
defined our parameters, other curious minds

can easily replicate this experiment, and
we can eventually pool all the data together

and have something solid to say about what

or at least the speed at which you can run

tool that you have for understanding other
people.
